FARLAM AJA
This is an appeal from a judgment of Mynhardt J, sitting in the Transvaal Provincial Division, who found that the rights to granite
and marble suitable for use as dimension stone were reserved in favour of respondent in the certificates of rights to minerals in
respect of the farms Grootvygenboom 248 and De Kom 252 in the district of Lydenburg.
The appeal was argued together with the case of The Minister of
Land affairs v Rand Mines Ltd an appeal from a judgment of Comrie J,
sitting in the Bophuthatswana Provincial Division. In that case
reservations of rights to minerals in terms which are to all intents and purposes identical to those in this case were considered.
For the reasons given in the judgment in that case, which is being handed down simultaneously with this one, the appeal in this case
is dismissed, together
3 with the costs occasioned by the employment of two counsel.
IG FARLAM
Acting Judge of Appeal.

applicants: Government of the Province of Northern Transvaal

sections.facts: The appeal arose from a judgment of Mynhardt J in the Transvaal Provincial Division, which held that the rights to granite and marble suitable for use as dimension stone were reserved in favour of Rand Mines Limited in the certificates of rights to minerals issued for farms Grootvygenboom 248 and De Kom 252 in the Lydenburg district. The appellants, the Government of the Province of Northern Transvaal and the Lebowa Mineral Trust, challenged that reservation.
sections.issues: The key issue was whether the reservation of mineral rights to granite and marble in the certificates of rights to minerals was valid and enforceable, and consequently whether the judgment of the lower court should be set aside.
sections.principles: The court referred to the principles established in the contemporaneous case Minister of Land Affairs v Rand Mines Ltd, where similar reservations of mineral rights were upheld. The precedent confirms that reservations expressly made in certificates of rights to minerals are legally effective and binding.
sections.application: Applying the precedent, the Supreme Court of Appeal found that the reservations in favor of Rand Mines Ltd were valid. Consequently, there was no basis to overturn the lower court's decision, and the appeal by the appellants was dismissed.
sections.conclusion: The appeal was dismissed and the appellants were ordered to pay the costs incurred by the respondent, including the employment of two counsel.
